values.alignmentText: India (.NET) offers steady openings in IT services and product firms. Bengaluru, Pune, and Hyderabad lead with many remote roles.
In India, 2D Environmental Artist pay trails top markets by ~25-30%; cost of living lowers the impact, and remote roles can improve total comp.
India offers occasional 2D environmental art workshops in major cities and strong online options; local in-person training is irregular.
India hosts multiple 2D environment art degree programs in metros (Mumbai, Bengaluru, Delhi). NID and Srishti help feed steady grads to studios.
India's major studios (Bangalore, Mumbai, Pune) have strong 2D environmental art pipelines. Most roles close in 1-2 months, with remote options.
India studios widely use English for 2D environmental art; some teams value basic local-language skills for collaboration.
India-based 2D environmental art roles in metros offer hybrid/remote setups with async workflows; full remote often negotiable.
India's 2D environmental artist pool is solid, with mid- and senior-level talent in hubs like Mumbai and Bengaluru; competition for senior roles is noticeable.
India 3D animator pay trails US/Europe by ~30-50%; lower cost of living helps, but senior roles often require remote or expat-friendly packages.
India has growing 3D animation upskilling via private schools and online platforms; occasional workshops in Mumbai/Bengaluru/Chennai; strong self-study options.
India has several strong animation programs (WWI, Srishti, MAAC) that graduate capable 3D animators annually with solid portfolios.
In India (IN), hubs like Mumbai/Bengaluru have strong animation talent; 3D animator roles close quickly, with screened candidates in 1–2 months.
In India, English is widely used in 3D animation studios. Hubs like Mumbai and Bengaluru often support bilingual teams.
India: 3D animator roles vary; Mumbai/Bengaluru studios often onsite, but case-by-case remote or hybrid options exist.
India has a large, seasoned 3D animation talent pool across major hubs Mumbai, Bengaluru, Hyderabad with strong outsourcing to global studios.
In India, 3D Character Artist pay trails top markets by ~25–30%; lower living costs help. Local studios offer growth, but global salaries aren’t matched.
India's metros (Bengaluru, Mumbai) have 3D animation schools (MAAC/Arena/Frameboxx) and online certs; in-person workshops are mainly in big cities.
India has several strong animation programs. Grads enter Mumbai/Bengaluru studios with solid portfolios.
India has a large pool of 3D artists; 3D character roles commonly close in 1–2 months, with hubs like Bengaluru, Mumbai, and NCR enabling quick hires.
3D Character Artist: Language in India: English is widely used in studios; some teams still value familiarity with a local language.
India (IN): Most game/3D studios support flexible remote models with equipment stipends. Hybrid/remote workflows are well established in major hubs.
India's 3D character artist pool is deep, with hundreds of specialists in Mumbai and Bengaluru and strong outsourcing ties to global studios.
In India, there are occasional accelerator cohorts for games; no nationwide dedicated game tracks.
India's major metros often exceed WHO PM2.5 limits; HEPA filtration and monitoring would be essential for the kids.
Anchored by Ubisoft Pune and other studios, India's game scene offers steady jobs and training in Pune, Bengaluru, and Mumbai.
In India (IN), secular law exists, but social pressure to join rituals persists; metros are more open to atheism than rural areas.
India's democracy remains resilient, but concerns exist. Press freedom issues, NGO restrictions, and majoritarian politics hint at moderate backsliding.
In India (IN), UPI rules; banks offer English support, but foreigners face lengthy KYC and local address proof requirements.
India's Goa/Kerala/TN beaches are family-friendly, but monsoon season and water quality variability limit reliable beach time.
Bengaluru and Mumbai host regular board-game meetups; families can participate, though imports are pricey and communities are smaller than Europe.
Body image pressure exists in urban India; media and peers push fitness norms. Emphasize health, inclusion, and confidence for Trey and Anduin.
India's diversified, tech-driven economy offers solid resilience; startups and IT hubs cushion downturns, but regional slowdowns can occur.
India's cancer incidence is rising; access to specialized oncology care can be strained outside major metros (e.g., Mumbai, Delhi).
India's prisons vary; overcrowding and delays persist, with abuses in some facilities. Reforms are ongoing, but detention experiences can be harsh.
In India, private daycares and nannies are common in cities. Government Anganwadi centers exist but reliability varies; plan backups.
In Indian cities, malls offer kids' zones. Yet traffic, air quality, and uneven sidewalks challenge family life.
In India, childcare support for middle-class families is limited; many rely on grandparents or hired help, with only modest public programs like ICDS.
In India, public childcare subsidies for foreigners are limited; visa families typically self-fund and rely on private providers.
In India, cricket, mobile gaming, yoga, and Bollywood dominate leisure; esports and tabletop cafes are growing in major metros.
India's major tech hubs (Bengaluru, Mumbai, Delhi) host frequent meetups and conferences; a vibrant dev community with regular events.
Urban India offers parks, gyms, and public health outreach, but access and quality vary by city. We should build local networks to stay motivated.
Intentional communities exist in India's major metros, but are limited; family-friendly co-living is niche—rely on informal networks in cities like Bengaluru, Mumbai, Delhi.
In India, community manager pay often trails top markets by 25-30%; cost-of-living offsets help your family's budget.
India has online CM courses and sporadic meetups in cities like Bengaluru and Mumbai; most upskilling is self-directed with occasional bootcamps.
India has broad marketing/communications programs; dedicated community-manager curricula are limited, so grads may need on-the-job upskilling and studio partnerships.
India's major hubs have a deep pool of community managers; most roles fill in 1-2 months, with remote options supporting a family plan.
India uses English widely in IT and gaming; local-language skills help in client-facing community roles.
India's tech hubs like Bengaluru and Pune increasingly support remote/hybrid CM roles. Prioritize reliable broadband and strong async workflows.
India has a large pool of seasoned community managers across IT/startups with outsourcing partners. English ubiquity is strong in Bengaluru, Mumbai, and Delhi.
In India, communities are warm and active, but building close ties takes some effort; expats often find welcoming local networks in cities.
India's established studios generally align with local pay medians after cost of living. Remote or hybrid options help families balance work and life.
In India, startup pay mixes cash + equity; remote roles common. In Bengaluru/Mumbai, comp tracks cost of living but stays below top markets.
India's FRRO/visa filings and periodic rule changes add friction. With proactive planning it's manageable, but the bureaucracy can vary.
India's major tech hubs (Bengaluru, Pune, Mumbai, Delhi) offer regular bootcamps, meetups, and online courses for web/game dev.
India has a strong freelancer market across IT and dev roles; rapid onboarding is common in major tech hubs (Bengaluru, Pune) to support Trey's needs.
India's strict NDPS laws can create immigrant criminal records for minor possession, risking visas and family stability.
India offers favorable payroll and office costs with a strong tech talent pool. Startup incentives and visas support studios in Bengaluru or Hyderabad.
In India, housing and local services are affordable versus the US; international schooling and imported goods can still add premium.
In India, major tech hubs like Bengaluru, Mumbai offer solid coworking and broadband; game-specific labs are limited, but quality spaces exist for indies.
India has a large IT talent pool, esp. in Bengaluru and Pune, for general dev roles. Game dev roles are tighter, but remote work helps.
Depression care in India varies; public systems have long waits and patchy coverage. Urban clinics offer faster private options, though at higher cost.
In India (IN), close ties grow with steady outreach—local clubs, neighbors, and shared meals; vulnerability is welcomed as trust builds.
In India, D&I commitments exist, esp. in urban tech hubs; progress varies by city and company; English prevalence supports expat families.
In India, enforcement varies by district. Monitor local areas to avoid heavy-handed policing.
India does not permit dual citizenship for most foreigners; OCI is for those of Indian origin, which this family lacks.
India has targeted grants and accelerators; early-stage capital for game-dev startups is typically $75k–$150k—best with private funding.
India has generalist VCs and government grants; game-specific backers are limited, but public schemes support early-stage game startups.
In India, GDP growth and a booming tech scene support families. Inflation and infra gaps demand careful budgeting.
In India, a growing mixed economy backs startups with grants and reforms, but bureaucracy is notable; fits Trey's goals yet requires patience.
India is startup-friendly with generally stable policy; elections bring manageable changes to visas, grants, and digital incentives for tech ventures.
Education quality in India varies by city; private/intl schools can offer strong academics and bilingual options. Public options may lag.
India has growing game-dev programs in major cities, but curricula often need industry-ready training. Internship and studio ties are expanding.
India sponsors skilled IT workers; hubs like Bengaluru, Hyderabad, Mumbai sponsor visas; dependents usually allowed.
India's game dev scene leans Unity, with growing Unreal presence; active meetups and cross-training exist across major tech hubs.
India has rich biodiversity and parks like Jim Corbett. Urban air and river pollution persist, so plan outdoor time carefully.
India resident taxes hover near 30% with surcharges. Deductions can ease the burden, but the rate stays meaningful for our family.
India fall after the monsoon brings 28-32°C days with humidity. Outdoor play is possible but remains sticky relative to the family's mild-weather goal.
In Indian cities, expat families can thrive with proactive networking and good schools, but must self-organize to access services.
India: dependents can join on family visas; spouses often can't work without permits, and adult dependents face extra hurdles.
India provides up to 26 weeks maternity leave for first child; access varies by employer, and bureaucracy can slow payout.
In India, family policy is modest and uneven; private schooling dominates; universal healthcare is improving but private care remains common.
India: visa families rely on employer policies; non-citizens have limited access to public childcare and welfare, increasing private costs.
In India's urban hubs, tidy smart-casual fits most settings; plan outfits modestly, but high fashion isn't required.
In India, metros mix Western casual and fusion; smaller towns stay modest; many workplaces still expect formality, while saris remain common in many settings.
Urban India blends Western casual with tailored kurtas for festivals. Trey can mix comfort with local style at work and in daily life.
In urban India, women enjoy autonomy but face subtle pressures around appearance and parenting choices.
India's strict gun laws mean private ownership is limited; firearms are uncommon and regulated, reducing daily risk for the family.
Consent education is improving in urban India, but harassment remains. For a family with young kids, prioritize clear boundaries and safety planning.
India's startup hubs (Bengaluru, Mumbai, NCR) have a growing founder network with regular meetups, accelerators, and mentorship for new teams.
In India, major metros offer good fresh markets and many cuisines, but specialty international options can be sporadic outside urban cores.
In India, urban neighbors are polite and open; with initiative you'll find warm connections and parent networks in expat-friendly areas.
In India, grant funding for indie game dev is modest but real. Expect roughly $50k–$125k per year via government and private programs.
India's game dev scene is growing, with studios in Pune/Bangalore; premium indie work remains niche, but remote roles and grants are expanding access.
In India, a third gender is legally recognized, but day-to-day acceptance remains uneven; urban centers are more accepting than rural regions.
In India, gender rights exist in law (POSH, equal pay) but enforcement gaps and safety concerns limit real-world impact.
In India, formal equality exists but social pressure reinforces classic roles. Urban hubs may feel egalitarian, yet traditional caregiving norms linger.
India's metros blend modern and traditional flirting. Nightlife still carries gendered scripts, but inclusive spaces exist.
In India visa holders must manage FRRO/police registrations and work-permit rules; organized records help avoid fines and status issues.
In India, rising heat and monsoon variability require housing resilience and cooling plans; aim for milder regions and proactive prep.
In India, startup visas are limited; founders typically rely on standard employment or business visas with local sponsorship.
In India, work culture often expects polished grooming. We budget time and money to fit in, but keep it practical for family life.
In India, polyamory isn't legally recognized; acceptance exists in urban progressive scenes like Mumbai/Delhi but institutions remain cautious.
Public hospitals in India are overstretched; middle-class families rely on private hospitals for timely care.
Expat insurance in India grants access to private hospitals with English-speaking doctors; air quality concerns and billing transparency can be an issue.
India's public universities (IITs/state colleges) are affordable for citizens but highly competitive; scholarships exist, based on merit.
India offers English-taught programs with international offices; fees vary, with private options and some scholarships excluding non-citizens.
India's established studios (Pune/Bangalore) typically fill roles in about 3 months. For US relocations, visa processing can extend to 3-4 months.
In India, early-stage startup hiring tends to take months; for Trey, expect 3-6 months with remote talent and strong English skills.
In India metros, gated 2-3 BHKs exist near parks for families, but water/power reliability and rental paperwork can slow secure leases.
In India, GST and IT returns are online; expat tax questions can be nuanced—professional advice helps ensure compliant filings.
In India, Western families are generally welcomed in urban centers; English helps daily life, but bureaucratic hurdles and local sensitivities can arise.
In India, white migrants may face enclave perceptions and cost frictions; we'll counter with proactive local engagement in neighborhoods and schools.
Public schools in India vary; many underperform, so families lean toward private schools and tutoring to ensure quality.
Public K-12 enrollment in India is possible but needs extra paperwork and local residence proof; expat families usually use private/international schools.
In India, English is common in business and higher education; local languages dominate daily life. In major cities, most services accommodate English.
In India, English is widely used in studios for cross-border work. Local languages remain important for community, compliance, and local partnerships.
In India, English is widely used in startups; local-language fluency aids hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
In India, general tech lawyers with some game IP experience exist; Bengaluru, Mumbai, Delhi offer options, but dedicated game-IP specialists are limited.
India: legal rights exist but social acceptance is mixed. Urban hubs like Mumbai/Delhi are more open, while rural areas vary.
India has a growing playtesting scene with agencies in Bengaluru and Delhi. Plan ahead for lead times; work with local firms for family-friendly tests.
In India, Marxist ideas persist regionally (Kerala/West Bengal) with open debate; national policy blends left influence with market reforms.
In India, breadwinner norms stay strong; urban Indian dads share childcare more, but emotional openness still lags.
Mass violence risk in India varies by region; several incidents in the past decade affect event planning. Rehearse safety plans and stay vigilant.
In India's tech hubs (Bengaluru, Mumbai, Delhi), meetups are frequent and robust; expect crowds but fast networking opportunities.
India's minimum wages vary by state and enforcement is uneven; for a two-parent, two-child family, minimum wage often doesn't cover city living costs.
India's Tier-1 metros offer fiber, metro rails, and new airports, but power outages and congestion still interrupt daily life; plan around service gaps.
In India, urban hubs may be tolerant, but non-monogamy still faces stigma; privacy and discretion are essential.
India's urban culture balances directness with tact; be candid about needs, but soften hard truths to respect local norms and hierarchies.
India offers diverse landscapes - from Himalayas to Kerala backwaters - great for family trips, but plan around peak seasons and park fees.
India faces cyclones on the eastern coast, Himalayan quakes in the north, and monsoon floods; risk is moderate but manageable with plans.
Weekend nature trips in India (Western Ghats/Nilgiris) are possible, but monsoon and travel times require planning.
In India metros, live music and Bollywood nights exist, but licensing rules and noise curfews limit spontaneity; family-friendly daytime events are common.
In Indian metros, nightlife exists in select districts, but safety concerns and alcohol rules often mean early closing times; family options are limited.
India hosts IGDC and IGDA India chapters (Bengaluru, Mumbai, Delhi); active meetups and online hubs support newcomers, though still smaller than Europe.
Notable studios like Zynga, Ubisoft, SuperGaming and Nodding Heads anchor Pune/Mumbai's game scene in India; collaboration for Trey.
In India, youth obesity is moderately common in urban areas. Monitor diet and activity to support schools and kids' play.
India's game startup scene has strong dev talent and growing accelerators; funding exists but often requires hustle.
Bengaluru, India: busy traffic with slower residential pockets; congestion and bureaucracy keep daily life on the hectic side.
In India, academics and routines are common; expect strong parental input and teacher guidance, with English-medium options easing your move.
In India (IN), naturalization typically requires around 12 years of residence and renunciation; not practical for this US family.
India's perceived corruption remains significant; petty bribes occur in some permit processes, but watchdogs and reforms exist.
In India's busy metros, personal space varies; expect closer contact in markets and transit. Gently set boundaries when needed.
In urban India, crowded transit and close greetings are common; respect cues and steer closer contact politely when needed.
In India, pleasant windows are short; winters are mild, but summers and monsoon humidity limit outdoor time. Plan outdoor activities mainly in winter.
India's federal democracy holds regular elections; active civil society helps counterbalance power, though regional politics and bureaucracy pose challenges.
In India, polyamory lacks legal recognition and faces social stigma. Privacy and discretion are essential for the kids and family.
India metros have many private preschools but fees are high; public Anganwadi/EC centers vary in quality; English-medium options are growing.
India offers CBSE/ICSE/IB private schools with strong English; tuition and admissions can be steep—check accreditation and values.
India's cities offer plentiful fresh markets that balance meals. Processed snacks are common, so mindful choices matter.
In India, PMM (Games) compensation trails top markets by 25–30%. Lower cost of living and family-friendly benefits help relocation though healthcare quality varies.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: India has limited local Game PMM education. Bengaluru, Mumbai, and Delhi host occasional programs, with most advanced topics online.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: India's PMM (Games) pipeline is growing; Bengaluru-Mumbai tech hubs partner with studios, but dedicated PMM programs remain limited.
India (IN) urban hubs (Bengaluru/Mumbai/Delhi): PMM (Games) hiring in 2–3 months; strong competition, but remote options widen the talent pool.
India PMM (Games): English is widely used; local language skills (Hindi/region) boost client-facing and regional campaigns.
India game PMM roles are usually hybrid; remote options exist, especially in tech hubs like Bengaluru and Mumbai, with periodic on-site days.
India's game PMM pool is moderate: strong marketing talent but niche game PMMs are scarce; startups may rely on remote hires or upskilling.
Major Indian metros (IN) demonstrate strong progressive activism and inclusive policies; state-level variation means progress is uneven nationwide.
In India, urban hubs show more sex-positive openness, but many rural areas remain conservative; privacy around relationships is common.
India messaging should center wellbeing and transparent facts, not nationalist spin. It aligns with the family's pluralistic, media-curious values in India.
In India, government-influenced media exists, but independent outlets and social platforms offer diverse voices; stay media-savvy and fact-check.
India's major metros (Delhi, Bengaluru, Mumbai) are expanding rail networks, but last-mile gaps and reliability push families toward rideshares.
India's growing indie scene offers regional events. Direct publisher access remains limited; rely on remote outreach and key conferences in major cities.
In India's metros, affluent families access strong private healthcare and international schools. Exclusive clubs can be gated and require planning.
In India, a two-income tech family with savings can access safe housing, healthcare, and schooling in metros; costs are manageable with budgeting.
In India, middle-income families can find affordable housing and good schools in many tier-2/3 cities; healthcare varies, but English is widely used.
India's game scene (Bengaluru/Mumbai) has strong real-time pipelines with Unity/Unreal. There is growing pre-rendered expertise across studios.
In India, faith groups lobby actively. Secular voices must monitor policy bias to protect the family's civil liberties.
In India, remote is possible case-by-case; hybrid is common, matching Trey/Sarah's preference for remote/hybrid options.
In India's startup scene (e.g., Bengaluru), hybrid/remote roles exist for tech work. On-site days are still common for core collaborations.
In Bengaluru/Pune, hybrid/remote norms predominate; coworking spaces ease collaboration, but US time zones may require late-evening calls.
India: residency is 1–5 years via employment/business visas; renewals depend on ongoing sponsorship and compliance, so long-term stays require planning.
In India, strong IT hubs and English-friendly cities support long stays; visa steps and schooling/healthcare gaps may cause occasional churn.
In India, retirement security is average; public pensions are modest, with many elders relying on family savings.
India: visa holders face limited public pension access; prioritize private retirement savings and employer schemes (PF/NPS) for the family.
Ruby openings in India are sporadic; Bengaluru/Pune host a few Rails roles, often requiring JS/DevOps skills, with remote options common.
Safe overall in many Indian neighborhoods; petty theft and traffic risks persist after dark; stick to family-friendly areas and plan transit.
India offers CBSE/ICSE and international schools; options vary by city, with English-medium options and competitive admissions needing early planning.
Coastal India (Arabian Sea & Bay of Bengal) waters stay ~26-29°C year-round. Swimming is comfortable outside the monsoon surf.
In India, monsoon rains and heat waves cause notable seasonal swings. Expect occasional outages and travel delays requiring planning.
In India, daylight is long in summer and ample in winter; mood stays strong with light-touch coping habits.
Bengaluru generally has mild weather, but pre-monsoon heat is humid and monsoons bring heavy rains, challenging Sarah's preference for gentle transitions.
India (Bengaluru, Pune, Hyderabad) has a deep senior startup tech bench; expect seasoned leaders, though compensation can be competitive.
In India, sexuality is mixed: urban centers are more open, but many areas remain conservative; polyamory faces stigma and limited resources.
India's social policies vary by state; core needs exist, but enrollment is often bureaucratic and programs are unevenly funded.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: In Indian metros, 2k sq ft rentals exist but sell fast; expect premium rents and broker help to find family-friendly areas with decent schools.
In Bengaluru, India, spring highs hover around 23-28°C (73-82°F), a generally comfortable range for outdoor activities.
India maintains solid democratic stability. Institutions function and courts operate despite regional protests, supporting predictable daily life.
India (IN) preserves plural democracy with constitutional rights; debates over minority protections and media freedom shape a diverse public sphere.
India's dynamic private sector sits between regulation and state influence; entrepreneurship thrives, but bureaucracy adds uncertainty.
Growing Indian game/animation scene with Bengaluru and Mumbai hubs; healthy studio presence across disciplines, though specialization favors a few niches.
In India, summers commonly reach 33-35°C with high humidity. Pools and reliable AC help keep Sarah and family routines intact.
In India, service can be brisk yet courteous; English is common in cities, and a local language helps. Interactions are efficient with occasional warmth.
India offers startup tax relief and SEZ benefits. Dedicated game incentives are limited and funding varies.
India visa process for US families: up to six months, moderate fees; e-Visas available for eligible entries, reducing in-person visits.
Trust in India's government varies by state; e-governance helps, but delays persist. As a US-origin family, we need simple, transparent processes.
In India, petty graft can occur in bureaucratic tasks. Digital services and oversight are improving transparency, especially in major cities.
In Bengaluru/Hyderabad, senior software pay is about ₹2.5–3.5M (~$30–42k) locally. Trey should target remote USD income.
Weekends in Indian cities offer malls, parks, and family outings. Sundays are active but traffic and crowds require planning or early starts.
India schools start around 7:30-8:00; IT teams often work late to coordinate with US clients, and traffic can make commutes long. Wraparound care helps but schedules still require juggling.
India's statutory annual leave typically starts at about 15 days per year plus public holidays; enforcement varies by state/sector.
In India, paid vacation typically runs about 20-24 days plus holidays. This supports a solid work-life balance for a small family.
India's vibrant outsourcing ecosystem spans art, QA, audio, and live-ops with scalable vendors across major hubs like Bengaluru and Mumbai.
India (IN): Real-time VFX pay lags top markets; seniors may require supplements; cost-of-living offsets help.
India offers occasional VFX real-time training with remote courses; Mumbai and Bengaluru host guest sessions and studios that run workshops.
India has several reputable VFX programs (NID, WWI, MAAC) feeding Mumbai/Bengaluru/Chennai studios with industry-ready grads.
In India, VFX Real-Time roles typically close in 1-2 months thanks to a large talent pool and remote-friendly studios.
English is widely used in India's VFX real-time studios (Mumbai, Bengaluru). Local-language basics help with onboarding and collaboration.
Remote VFX (real-time) roles in India exist case-by-case. Expect hybrid or on-site in hubs like Bengaluru or Mumbai to fit your family's needs.
India has a strong real-time VFX talent pool with many mid-to-senior artists across studios. Mumbai and Bengaluru are key hubs.
Neighbors show mixed signals: tense with Pakistan and China, pragmatic with Nepal and Bangladesh; for a new family in India, day-to-day life is rarely affected.
India's diverse democracy inspires pride and healthy patriotism, while recognizing challenges and safeguarding civil liberties.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: In India, neighbors have mixed views: Bangladesh/Nepal cooperate; Pakistan/China tensions temper perceptions of its regional role.
India offers E visas with employer sponsorship and X dependent visas; no residency-by-investment route. Expect thorough processing and variable timelines.
Walkability in Indian cities is mixed. Sidewalks can be irregular and traffic can be heavy, making family strolls stressful.
In Indian metros, US migrants are generally welcomed; robust expat networks and English usage ease integration, though bureaucracy can be slow.
India's ancient culture and booming tech hubs in Bengaluru and Pune fuel constant storytelling for Trey. Daily discoveries keep the family engaged.
Winter in India varies: Delhi can have near-freezing nights, Bengaluru remains mild (15-27°C).
In India (IN), tech roles typically run 45-48 hours/week; remote/hybrid options exist, so negotiate to protect family evenings.
In India, tech work hours vary by company. Many teams offer flex schedules to support Sarah's family priorities.
India: protections exist on paper, but enforcement is uneven; gig/contractor rights lag as IT sector protections evolve.
